newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Oracle sees strong ASEAN growth.
newsitem.headline: Oracle sees strong ASEAN growth.

text.p: Database software company Oracle Corp expects revenues in the Southeast Asian region to grow more than 50 percent this year, managing director Edmund Ang said on Wednesday.

Speaking to Reuters after the launch of the updated Oracle8 database software, Ang said: "In the last five years, Oracle has been growing at about 50 percent a year in ASEAN (Association of South East Asian Nations)...growth this year will be more than 50 percent."
The ASEAN region for Oracle comprises Singapore, Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia and Brunei.
Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Pakistan will also be grouped under this division in the current financial year.
Ang said ASEAN contributed to 21 percent of Asia-Pacific revenues in the last financial year ended May 31, 1997.
He declined to give actual revenues from ASEAN but said the Asia-Pacific contributed to 14 percent of total group revenues, which rose last year to US$5.68 billion, up 35 percent.
Ang said ASEAN will raise its contribution to 25 percent of Asia-Pacific revenues in the current financial year.
Among the fastest growing countries in the region are Indonesia, where there are several infrastructure projects, and Vietnam, which was starting from a low base, he said.
He said Singapore was currently the region's largest market, accounting for 33 percent of revenues.
"But in the longer-term, I expect Indonesia will catch up because there are so many projects going on there."
More than half of the revenues from the region are from sales of Oracle products but the group's consultancy business was also growing at a very fast pace, he added.
